reviewText: I'm a sucker for shows from the British Isles. This one begs comparison with The Vicar of Dibley, with a new priest trying to fit into a rural town full of oddball characters. It's nowhere near as funny, though there are spots where it tries to be. On the positive side, both the characters and the dramatic story lines are much easier to take seriously for being a little less zany.
summary: Wonderful genre but thin on content

reviewText: Each episode in this series is a remarkably crafted and performed story.  The characters are not only real and alive, you become connected to them as you move through the episodes.It's interesting to note that although the series was produced some time ago, with rather "primitive" production values compared to today's extravaganzas, it simply evaporates as the stories unravel.  Each episode is a unique tale.  These are simple, but very appealing, characters.My wife observed the other night that at the end of each episode we find ourselves smiling.  Good stuff; don't miss it.

reviewText: We started watching this series a few weeks ago and were hooked instantly.  It is nice to see a light comedy without a lot of the slapstick that many have.  It tells a moral story as well and the characters meld together very well. Lots of episodes so it will take quite a while to go through them all.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This is a great CLEAN show about an English priest (Peter Clifford) sent as local priest to the Ballykissangel Church. His attempts to lead God's flock gets intermingled with the other characters who meet at the local public house (Fitzgeralds) run by agnostic Asumpta Fitzgerald who has a disregard for the Church - but is inching toward re-birth as a parishoner (my opinion) because of respect for Father Clifford. Add "money & fame schemer" Brian Quigley and his 2 ner-do-well employees to the mix and you've got a great and fun show.
summary: Funny and captivating small Irish town life
